subject: Re: [junit] JUnit 4 restructuring
msgSnippet: ... Interestingly, I can t say that I work with a lot of closed-source Java API s, so I can t comment on that either. However, I can say that I have seen
messageBody:
On 11/2/05, Elliotte Rusty Harold <elharo@...> wrote:
>
> Cédric Beust ♔ wrote:
>
> >
> > That's a completely separate debate and in my experience, closed source
> > software is usually much better at publishing and maintaining API's than
> > open-source (Microsoft being a pretty good example), but let's save this
> for
> > another day.
>
> On this, I guess our experiences really do differ. I work hardly at all
> with Microsoft APIs, but in the Java world, the open source stuff tends
> to be as well or better documented than the proprietary stuff.


Interestingly, I can't say that I work with a lot of closed-source Java
API's, so I can't comment on that either. However, I can say that I have
seen open-source Java API's that are excellent and just about as many that
are horrendous, hence my disputing your argument that "open source API's are
usually better than closed source ones". I'm not saying one is better than
the other, just that the quality of API's seems to have nothing to do with
whether these API's are open or closed source.

As for Microsoft, I was simply pointing out that they are excellent at
maintaining backward compatibility for API's. You can literally run in 2005
programs that were written in 1995.


Sure there's a lot of poorly documented, poorly written open source
> software,
> but this tends to sink to the bottom and fall out of use pretty quickly.
> The libraries people actually use are much better documented than their
> proprietary equivalents. (Probably effect rather than cause, but either
> way...) I suspect it also matters that one of the easiest ways for
> someone to contribute to a project is to start writing some
> documentation patches. This means open source documentation tends to
> improve with time. Proprietary documentation rarely does.


That I disagree with.

Popularity is what brings quality in documentation, and it works for closed
and open source alike. If a closed source software becomes popular and
generates a big community, the documentation will follow. It's no different
than the open source world.

But we should probably stop this discussion since it's clearly off-topic for
this list.

--
Cédric


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
